So, don't ask me how, but it works again! Even though it's a folder created by my mail provider. My mail provider, btw, is MS Outlook, and it has a fixed retention policy of 10 days.

So, still a mystery.

content:
Perdona la franchezza, ma forse dovresti rivedere il tuo metodo di lavoro. Nel senso che dei dati importati bisogna sempre fare un backup, siano documenti di Word, file PDF o email. I programmi informatici non sono infallibili, i sistemi operativi si impallano, gli antivirus cancellano cose a caso, gli hard disk si rompono. Il backup dovrebbe essere la norma.

Detto questo, assicurati anzitutto di fare ora un backup della cartella del profilo di Thunderbird -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo

Poi:

  1. vai in Tasto menu > Visualizza > Cartelle ed assicurati che la voce Tutte le cartelle sia spuntata
  2. Se questo non risolve, controlla nel backup fatto sopra se le cartelle mancanti sono ancora presenti (Una cartella Thunderbird corrisponde ad un file senza estensione con lo stesso nome)

content:
Is your question that you want to change default to unthreaded? If so, here is the info: This is the official (to my knowledge) documentation. Well worth the read https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Here is my own documentation on threading, duplicating the above, but it may help: You need to highlight each folder and click View>sort by>unthreaded. If this applies to just a few folders, just repeat the process as necessary. If you have many folders or plan to add many new folders, you may wish a different approach, below:

More info: To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags 0=unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right. 

 ------------

To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: (I creates a crude video that walks through the steps at 

   https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4  that demonstrates the following steps: 
   First, highlight a folder that you have set to unthreaded	    In the Message List view, in the column header, on the far right, open the options button that shows         context menu. :    At the very bottom is the option:    -> "Apply current view to..."    -> "Folder and its children..."    -> Hover over an account    -> In the next menu don't select a folder. Instead select the account name itself.
creator: davidsk

content: Okay, I solved the problem. I was not able to find Profiles (or about:profiles). What I did find was Profile Directory under Application Basics. As I was looking around, I found in the Account Settings, to the new profile, a Local Folders that showed the Local Directory location. I was able to change the Local Directory location to my Local Folders for my old profile which still had the archived emails in it.

content: Try this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'Profiles' in left sidebar - click 'about:profiles' - This will list any profiles that Thunderbird is aware of.

content: Do you have the menu bar showing? If not, click the 'alt' button and then you can click view>toolbars>menu bar. That's good for a start. The new TB has a unified toolbar that did not exist before and you can rightclick and add many buttons to it. Please be patient in working through this as I think you will like the new setup once you have the basics set to your preferences. Going back would only postpone this transition. If you have further problems, please post as screenshot of what you see and that will help others here give feedback.

content:
Would you mind terribly telling us what exactly you are seeing that you don't like, where you're seeing it, what version of Thunderbird you're running, and what your OS is?

We may be able to help you fix this if we know the details of what you think is broken.

For now, please go to Settings > General > Language & Appearance > Fonts and Colors, use the Default Font drop-down to choose a font you like, then in the Size drop-down, choose 17, and then in the Advanced button menu, choose Latin and set the higher number to 17 and the lower number to 14 and then hit OK.

Close and restart Thunderbird.

Try it. I think you'll like it.

content:
It's possible to colour the cell background of unread messages with userChrome: 

/* threads pane unread bg colour */ #threadTree tr[data-properties~="unread"] {background-color:pink !important;}


Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Directory (Win: Open Folder), close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the colour as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

content:
Ok, I might agree with you, but all I am as confused. It took me ages to work out you were referring to the appmenu.

So I have some suggestions that might work. 1. Use the menu bar (right click on the tab bar and select menu. Is has the entries you seek on it's Tools menu. 2. Use Thunderbird to automatically move messages marked as junk to the junk folder. Periodically check the junk messages in the junk folder for an false positives and right click and select empty Junk from the context menu. Note you can empty the junk folder that way without actually opening it by right clicking the folder, but I would not really recommend deleting without first reviewing.

content:
In che senso 'nessuno deve pagare'? Tu lavori gratis? Oppure, perché non se ne occupa KDE o la tua distro? Ancora, sei sicuro che l'errore sia di Mozilla? Thunderbird lo hai scaricato dai server Mozilla o dai repository della tua distro?

A tutta l'invettiva su Linux, su Ubuntu e tutto il resto preferisco non rispondere proprio. Sono 20anni che sento queste inutili polemiche (e te lo dico da utente AntiX...)
creator: @next

content:
Grazie @Next.

Finora non si era così scassata la coerenza dei colori, ma ora e' davvero terribile. Nessuno deve pagare per aggiungere una semplice app come ha fatto Firefox dove con le ultime versioni mi e' successa la stessa cosa, ma li ho trovato gia' installato "Firefox color" ed e' stato un lampo ricreare la stessa coerenza di prima. La cosa che da fastidio e' che si pensa a linux esclusivamente come ubuntu, ubuntu fa gli elementi arancioni? Beh ci basta fare tutto arancione per linux, ubuntu fa il tema gtk a due tonalità di grigio scuro? Allora ci basta fare thunderbird "zebrato" a due grigi, ubuntu usa il blu come colore di hover? Beh in linux l'hover e' blu e basta.

Dove lo devo mettere sto user.css e cosa ci dovrei scrivere dentro? Non lo trovo piu' nella cartella di thunderbird ormai da un po' di anni.
creator: clrpla74

content:
Si può fare con il file userChrome.css, ma è sconsigliato e non supportato -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/userChromecss-userChromejs-userContentcss-non-supportati#

Alla seconda domanda, chi paga per fare una versione personalizzata per ogni ambiente grafico, per ogni tema grafico e per ogni distribuzione?

creator: Bob_Blaylock

content: I don't know why some users see a sudden change in fonts after the upgrade, as I didn't see it myself. Instead of doing an in-place upgrade, I always install new major releases in a separate directory and create a new profile, leaving the previous release and profile accessible and independent.
creator: sfhowes

content:
That seems to have done it.

  But a question remains, is why updating to the latest version caused the font size to suddenly become so small in the first place.
creator: Bob_Blaylock

content: Try View/Font Size from the Menu Bar or the 3-bar AppMenu.

creator: cor-el

content: Thanks for your suggestion. This is one of the items I found and implemented yesterday when searching for a solution to my issue. I've also tried changing the settings for date and time from 'Use system timezone' to 'Set timezone manually' but no matter what I select, the listed emails remain 1 hour too early. My time zone I believe is currently GMT -11 but no matter what offset I select (eg GMT -5), the listed time of emails remains the same (even after quitting and restarting the Thunderbird app). Any further suggestions for a fix would be much appreciated. A screen shot of my privacy.resistFingerprinting settings is attached.
creator: admin410

content:
If you have enabled "Resist Fingerprinting", set this pref on the about:config page to false to disable this feature.

  • privacy.resistFingerprinting => false
  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/about-config-editor-firefox
  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/firefox-protection-against-fingerprinting
creator: cor-el

content:
Moving to and using virtual drives is a very bad idea.

If you are using imap accounts I don't see any reason why your folder structure and mails listed would not be correct.

content:
Update: I've found that hitting a key on the keyboard whilst reading a message that resists being marked as read immediately marks it as read : )

For me, the 'm' (for mark) is convenient and seems quicker than i.e. the spacebar!

Hope this helps narrow it down for the devs.
creator: Jay.Dear

content:
Ah, yes, that's Firefox's version [grin], jumping back and forth between the two I was. Sometimes hard to spot which app you're in when using dark mode.

I just noticed that hitting F5 gets rid of all the 'new message' diamonds in a flash but doesn't otherwise seem to affect the issue.
creator: Jay.Dear

content:
Thanks for reporting this. There is an existing bug report. It may take some time to find the cause.

Note, We don't have a v118.0.1. Perhaps you mean 115.3.1 ?
creator: wsmwk

content: This is the way imap works, you delete or change a message in mail client X, it is propagated and seen in other mail clients.
